Dear  Deep Look, that was a great video as you can tell by the responses n all these comments!! I ve bn going to the same bch every spring during the full n new moon tides for over 15 years in NJ!! I used to fish there but it’s impossible to do that during these spawns, so now l jst go w a couple close friends, to take in this spectacle n to help the exhausted , upside down n stranded Horseshoe crabs back to the water !! It’s very sad watching them struggle to flip themselves back over n eventually, due to exhaustion, lack of oxygen or moisture they die !! I have another concern n l’m hoping maybe someone can let me knw the answer !! In the last 3 to 4 years we’ bn seeing more n more females covered in big barnacles n other nasty freeloading creatures, excuse my lack of proper names for these things , but sme are so encrusted in these things that their eyes are covered , their hinges aren’t moving right!!! Will it harm the horseshoe crabs if we remove sme of these things, is really what l wnt to knw ?? It’s nver discused in any video or written discussion that l cn find!! Any info would be greatly appreciated!! We spend frm 6-10hrs a night helping these amazing creatures!! If there’s more we can do for them, we are all in!! Thanks again!!

seems only a few weeks ago i was watching a video on a top 5 of fossilized animals that were locked in time forever. on this list was a Horseshoe crab. the fossil starts with the trail it left behind. its "Death March". the small horseshoe crab falls through a very salty sea, and lands on its back. it then struggles before righting itself up, then making a trail in the sand, trying to escape. you can see from the fossil trail that this horseshoe crab is distressed from its dangerous situation, changing direction every now and then and trying to lift itself up. eventually the trail ends. the perfectly preserved fossil of a horseshoe crab. it didn't escape the toxic water.

When I was a young'un, growing up near Tampa, FL, my grandfather would take me to the beach a lot.  Sometimes, you could see a stray horseshoe crab and my grandfather liked to collect the shells of the dead ones left on the beach.  I was always scared of their huge spike-tail, but also very fascinated by them.  All these years later, seeing them in videos like these piques my curiosity and brings me back to my childhood, and the youthful wonder I felt when I encountered these alien creatures.

You really need to augment these videos with facts about human impact. Horseshoe crabs' blood is harvested for pharmaceutical needs, and something like 30%-50% of them die from the process. If it takes 10 years for one to mature and only a few survive from the thousands of eggs each one lays, that is not going to be sustainable for much longer. Rising ocean acidity and temperature is also going to start killing them in the near future. -_-

The eggs are also important food for migrating shorebirds.
